title: How to properly read the Bible for the first time - Quora

response.answer_text: The fact you are even the smallest bit interested in reading proves that you recognize you have a spiritual need, sadly most do not (even some in religions). Hopefully you are reading it as you want to get to know God. The Psalms are very comforting as well as enlightening and when reading about the lives of ones like King David, we get to see that they made mistakes just as we do and the fact they feature in the bible is very heart warming because if the bible was not from God you can bet your life that the mistakes of Kings etc would not be in there. If you want to know about Jesus then the four gospels Matthew, Mark, Luke and John tell about his birth, life and death. Some start at Genesis and read through to Revelation which gives you all the history from the beginning, but if you know little of scripture then that is probably not the best way to do it, the bible is a hard book in places and maybe you should ask yourself some questions beforehand like what do you want to know and why? I would get a good study bible that has cross references in it and if possible a concordance. Are you seeking knowledge, truth or both? Believe me when I say there is a difference as I found out for myself. What do you intend to do with this knowledge once you have acquired it? Are you willing to act upon what you learn? Many do not. There are so many reasons that people decide to look into the bible and for many it is because they want answers to life’s big questions: How did we get here? Why are we here? Is there a purpose to life? Why is there so much suffering? Why do we get sick grow old and die? Why is there so much crime? Why do people fight and war with one another? Is there any hope for a better future? What is the future for the earth? If you believe in God then that is admirable and if you really want to know him then that takes effort but you will not be disappointed and your efforts will not be in vain. Pray from your heart to God, through the name of Jesus his Son, as he is our mediator, and ask God to help you to find him and gain accurate knowledge of him and his purpose, he will help you by pouring out his holy spirit to open your spiritual eyes, he desires all people to live and invites all to come to him, so when reading a few verses ask yourself what it tells you about God and how it applies to you personally. Jesus said in Luke 11:9 “So I say to you, keep on asking,+ and it will be given you; keep on seeking, and you will find; keep on knocking, and it will be opened to you.”+ Hope that helps.

Here's how I was taught to read the Bible the first time, and it was amazing: Pick a gospel (Matthew, Mark, Luke or John), and read 1 chapter a day. Get your notebook out, and answer these 5 questions: What was Jesus (or the other people mentioned) doing?With or to whom was Jesus doing it?Why was he doing it?How can I imitate Jesus heart in that today?What questions do you have about what happened, or what was written?If the questions don't seem to apply or you can't figure it out, don't stress it, just move on and try the next chapter the next day. Next read Acts, Romans, and keep going in the New Testament. This will challenge anyone, even the seasoned Christian. I came to believe in Jesus and built my faith in God and the Bible doing this, and still go back to it 20 years later. Here's why it was amazing: as I tried this, I changed. Changed like for the better, and not just in small ways. It wasn't even like a New Year's resolution kind of change, either, it was gradual, and barely noticeable to me. It was, however, striking to those around me. I became more like Christ - which isn't as hard as it seems. If you're any kind of a selfish, arrogant, socially awkward goober with low-self esteem like I was, there's no nowhere to go but up! If you want to become more kind, loving, patient, pure-minded, serving, humble and giving, learn from the Master - and I don't mean me! If you want to know if the Bible is true or not, Jesus left us an simple way to figure it out: “If you hold to my teaching, then you are really my disciples. Then you will know the truth, and the truth will set you free.” (John 8:31a–32, NIV, emphasis mine) Try to find a Christian whom you respect, and ask them to give you some guidance on it, maybe meeting with you regularly until you get going with it. If you can't find one, message me. Last thing: I'd be happy to offer some intro Bible studies to anyone interested. Please message me if you are.

The Bible is a massive library of 66 books. It can be quite daunting to read it, at first. Few people are able to begin at Genesis and read through the whole 1189 chapters to Revelation 22 the first time they try it. I hope you have a Bible that is written in the language you speak. Translations like the New Living Translation or the Good News Bible are easier to understand than many other English Bibles. The New International Version and the Holman Christian Standard Bible [which will soon be available as the Christian Standard Bible, in an updated edition] are also reasonably easy to read. If you don’t have copies of these, you can find them at A searchable online Bible in over 150 versions and 50 languages. It is a good idea to begin by reading the first chapters of the Bible in Genesis. You may soon find it overwhelming, and if so, put it aside and read another part of the Bible. I suggest you begin reading the short books of the Bible such as Mark [the shortest Gospel] 1 John and other short New Testament books like Jude and Philemon In the Old Testament, you could read a few psalms from the Book of Psalms, read the lovely story of Ruth and the story of Jonah. If you feel like you are getting the hang of it, read another Gospel, and then read Acts, the story of what happened after Jesus died and was resurrected. Then, you might like to tackle the whole New Testament. I’m currently reading the whole Bible through for the fourteenth time and am thoroughly enjoying it. I hope you get hooked and keep reading and loving God’s Word, and taking up its offer of putting your trust in Jesus Christ, our Lord and Saviour.

Get a study Bible and/or Concordance. and find an affable group of informed people to study with. The study Bible’s translation and organization will vary according to the faith and/or tradition you choose: e.g. Roman Catholic Bibles will contain more books which are considered divinely inspired versus Protestant bibles, and the titles of the books may differ slightly. In some historical translations, English-speaking Catholics will call Jonah “Jonas” or Noah “Noe”, etc. The Book of Revelation in older Catholic translations will be called the Apocalypse of St John the Apostle. But don’t get bogged down in sectarian disputes as to which Bible is authentic, such disputes are for fundamentalist philistines who have not studied the Bible’s evolution in its complexity and richness. This brings me to my last point: in addition to a Study Bible, find an Bible Study group to read with. As with translations, Bible Study groups may follow a particular faith or tradition. I recommend a group led by an ordained minister from a mainline Protestant tradition from an accredited divinity school. (e.g. Doctor of Divinity from Harvard or a large university) Or, choose a Catholic group led by a priest or Franciscan. Or choose a liberal tradition which ordains women. The reason I recommend more educated biblical study groups is that you may get more tolerant, non-literal diverse readings of passages pertaining to things like homosexuality and sin. My experience with these Bible study groups run by ministers with minimal educational backgrounds from small, unaccredited bible colleges is that their readings are idiosyncratic and geared towards the agenda of the small church pastors whose interpretations are rigid, dogmatic and outright manipulative. Hope that helps.

If you’re new to reading the Bible you’ll want to start with the following: Get a good Bible. You need a modern translation of the Bible that has helpful introductions to each book, maps and occasional charts, and ideally study notes. I recommend you go to your local bookstore and seek out a “Study Bible.” NIV and NRSV are great translations. You’ll find others as well.Decide what’s important to you. Do you want to understand Christianity better? Then begin in the New Testament and move to the Old Testament later, perhaps using the cross-reference notes that you’ll find in your study Bible. (For example, the Gospel of Matthew has countless Old Testament references throughout. You could begin with Matthew and when you get curious flip back to the Old Testament book that is quoted and go from there.) Do you want to understand the entire Biblical narrative better? Then I’d suggest beginning with the New Testament Book of Acts, which has a number of long speeches that put the Old Testament in Context. Then switch back and read Genesis & Exodus, Deuteronomy, Joshua, Judges, 1 Samuel, then 2 Samuel. You’ll get the whole history that way.Finally, consider inviting a friend to join you in daily reading. That is, ask a friend to read the same passages as you each day, and meet once a week to talk about what you’ve read. Ideally you would enlist 3–5 friends and you could all agree to do the same reading and discuss weekly. Scripture is meant to be interpreted. Thus, it gives a great payoff if people are willing to read and discuss together. You’ll go much deeper through the eyes and insights of your friends.

When laying bricks for a building in ancient times, you would start with the cornerstone. And yet that is one place where people often do not start when reading the Bible, and, consequently, it is the place they will never reach either. All over the world, there are people who have been in churches for many decades, and yet they have never encountered the Jesus of the four gospels, who is referred to in scripture as “the cornerstone which the builders rejected”. His teachings are found in the four gospels: Matthew, Mark, Luke & John. A collection of some of his best teachings can be found in just three chapters of Matthew (5, 6, & 7). Those three chapters end with a sobering story about people who would listen to that sermon and then not act on what Jesus said in it. Here’s a video I produced which gives some helpful advice on how to get started studying the Bible. It’s less than fifteen minutes long: The Whole Bible in Less Than 15 Minutes!

This is similar to how one begins a journey of a 1000 miles. He takes one step. Then another. Each of us plows our own field. If you want to learn about Jesus, its one of the Gospels. If you are interested in Moses, its Exodus or Numbers or one of the Pentateuch. If you want poetry, Psalms. If you are wanting wisdom, Proverbs or Ecclesiates. I used to do weights training, and I found it quite helpful to have a training partner. I was always there at the appointed time. Make an Bible study appointment with a buddy, and study it together. Listen to your pastor. He should be good at explaining it. If you want some time with him, make an appointment. I always had time to discuss scriptures with parishioners. If you like, there are groups like Navigators and Bible Study Fellowship who exist to study the Bible more closely. If after a year you are still at sea, wanting a discipline, you probably can benefit from one of these hints. As to where to start, I always like John's gospel. But it is fun to read Paul also, or Torah or the wisdom books. Get some help with the history for Kings and Chronicles, and some expert help for Daniel.

Where do I start if I never read the Bible? If you never read the bible, the one thing you do not want is anybody’s opinion about what it should say. So no “study bibles”, no commentaries, no tracts, no goofy preachers live or tv. Sit down by yourself with only a bible and read. It is not reliable to let people tell you what the bible says. Many people will make up stuff because they don't know what it says, and many will make up stuff because they wish it would not say what it says. You just have to read it for yourself. Read a chapter of Proverbs every day. Proverbs has 31 chapters so you can keep your place by just looking at a calendar. There is no religion or nothing in Proverbs and you don't have to believe anything. Just read to find wisdom. When you are comfortable with that, then read the bible from Romans to 2 Thessalonians over and over until you start to remember passages. That is the part that applies to Christians. In about three weeks of this study you will know more bible than the average seminary graduate. That is because seminary students study other people’s opinions ABOUT the bible, rather than studying the bible. Of course there will be passages that you don’t understand. When that happens, keep reading. It will usually be explained. If that doesn’t work then write your question and put the paper in a safe place. Eventually God will send understanding and then you can retire the paper.

The best way is where you start. I began in Matthew and then Genesis. But there is no rule. If you want to know what Jesus did when He first came you can read Matthew, Mark, Luke or John. These are 4 different accounts. Two are eyewitnesses and one was a doctor and the first one was a disciple. If you want to know how everything began then you read Genesis. If you want to know future events then you read the prophets and revelation. For wisdom you read the proverbs. For poetry and songs you read psalms. For Church history specifically the time immediately following Christ’ departure you read acts. For education you would read Roman's until Hebrews. Hebrews is meant for deeper learning and study. John is meant for end of life and encouragement. Peter is for recovery and life lessons and preparations for the end of the world. The entire book from Genesis to Revelation is all about Jesus Christ. There are many other categories and themes that can be learned from the book. But in an open environment with atheists mocking i would specifically have you learn what King David said. “The fool has said in his heart that there is no God.”

On first reading the Bible, it is normal to interpret the verses “literally-physically”. LESSON ON MORALITY AND BENEFIT FOR THE BODY 1. From the Ten Commandments: · Exo 20:13 Thou shalt not kill. · Exo 20:14 Thou shalt not commit adultery. · Exo 20:15 Thou shalt not steal. 2. John the Baptist doubting Jesus Christ: Luk 7:22 Then Jesus answering said unto them, Go your way, and tell John what things ye have seen and heard; how that the blind see, the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed, the deaf hear, the dead are raised, to the poor the gospel is preached.The result of the foregoing is RELIGIOSITY as we see Christianity today many sects and denominations. FOR A SERIOUS BIBLE READER, THE FOLLOWING IS THE GUIDE The primary purpose of the Bible is the “salvation of the soul”, and not the benefit of the body. However, this needs true and sincere “spiritual humility” as Jesus Christ said: · Mat 18:3 And said, Verily I say unto you, Except ye be converted, and become as little children, ye shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven. Then your eyes will be “opened” and see the following: · Joh 6:63 It is the spirit that quickeneth; the flesh profiteth nothing: the words that I speak unto you, they are spirit, and they are life [spiritual not physical life]. · 2 Cor 4:18 While we look not at the things which are seen, but at the things which are not seen: for the things which are seen are temporal; but the things which are not seen are eternal. · 2 Cor 3:6 Who also hath made us able ministers of the new testament; not of the letter [not literal but spiritual interpretation], but of the spirit: for the letter killeth, but the spirit giveth life. This is SPIRITUALITY that many Bible believers have “not seen”. That is why Jesus Christ said: · Mat_20:16 So the last shall be first, and the first last: for many be called, but few chosen.

I'll say: start from the beginning and bite your way down. See it as a book of stories and sayings, what people did, including God, and what they said. There are people, places, plans and purposes. You don't need anyone pulling you by the nose, you don't need any special way to approach it as if it is an esoteric book that only the experienced can know. But I will only advice that you get away from the king James version, because of its achaic language. You can enjoy the Bible in almost any other version. Also determine to read a minimum number of chapters a day depending of how much time you want to devote to it. In addition, consider journaling. Writing focuses you understanding. I believe why you are reading is more important than how you are reading. The mind you bring to it will determine what you will get out of it. I set out to finish the reading the Bible within a year, reading four chapters a day, and that was exactly what I did some time ago.

You do not say how mature a reader you happen to be. It would make a difference in my recommendation. My ten year old has read the Bible, King James Version, from cover to cover but I do not expect him to understand vast amounts of it. It is always good to read through it a couple of times before digging in to study it. You have to know what it says before you can understand it. That being said, if you are after a crash course to get up to speed on the basics I would recommend reading Genesis and the beginning chapters of Exodus up to and including Chapter 23. This will give you a little historical background so you have some reference of what the New Testament is speaking of. From there read Romans. Romans is a explanation and description of God’s plan of salvation. If you remember what you read from verse to verse and chapter to chapter you should have little trouble grasping the information. After, I would read Hebrews and then start reading the whole New Testament. You will not understand Revelations but that does not matter now; read the Old Testament next, you will not understand it all, read it anyway. I wish you well in your desire to know God’s word.

The Bible is a dangerous book if you are younger than 40 years old. Get a life first. The stories in the Bible are neither fiction nor history nor myth. It is a qabalistic work that hides a non-dualistic philosophy that can be used to create the life of your dreams. But to learn this philosophy can be destabilizing, to say the least. This philosophy also allows those in the know to brainwash vast numbers of people (around 3 billion by now) and hide the truth from them about themselves. Those in the know will downplay the meaning of the text, but the truth is, it is their source for techniques on mind control. The key to understanding the Bible is three-fold: 1. abandon all things you think you know about it - the Hebrew Bible (aka Old Testament) is unrelated to the New Testament addition, 2. learn the meaning of the Hebrew letters (see my profile for resources) and 3. read the texts in their original language (do not accept translations because they hide the original meaning by using subtleties to promote a theology of the translator’s choice). If you read it without an understanding of ancient multilayered texts, but instead try to read it at face value, you risk being infected with a mind virus that will turn your life into turmoil. It will be the source of your worst nightmares for decades to come. For what it’s worth, I speak from experience.

You have 2 choices. Start at the beginning (Genesis) or begin with the Book of John. If you start with John, read 1, 2, 3 John as well, then go to Matthew, then Mark and Luke. Afterwards, read Acts and Romans, then Paul’s letters to the churches in Greece. Read James, 1–2 Peter, and Jude. Then go to Genesis. Read about the beginnings of the Israelites (Exodus through Ruth). Read the Prophets (Isaiah, Jeremiah, Daniel, Ezekiel). If possible, while reading Daniel, read Revelation (they coincide). After this, read whatever’s left. Read the History of the Israelites (1–2, Samuel, 1–2 Kings, 1–2 Chronicles). Read Esther and the other Prophets. Read Hebrews, then the poems/philosophy (Psalms, Proverbs and Ecclesiastes). Read Lamentations and Job. Save Song of Solomon for last. This will give you an understanding of the metaphor that is Jesus (Bridegroom) and the Church (Bride).

I haven't read all the answers, but my thought would be that the bible is the word of God. Literally He speaks to us through this book and the scripture says His (Gods) ways are higher than mens ways. So the very first thing I would do is go to Him in prayer. I would ask Him for guidance and understanding, ask Him for help you realize what He is saying to you personally. Then I would open His word and I would start reading. I would meditate on what I read and see how it would apply to me. I would try to be brutally honest with myself.( God disciplines the ones He loves) Discipline is just correction of your way of thinking. Let His words and wisdom mold and cause you to become more in His ways, not in ours. Finally I would pray to Him often and thank Him for the opportunity of having a relationship with Him. Sorry I am so long winded. This subject and having a good relationship with Jehovah God touched my heart. Sometimes it is a cold dark place without God.

The beginning Bible student should start in the Gospels with the first book, Matthew. Most start in Genesis and by the time they get to the he begat him, him begat so and so, so and so begat this guy, they put the Bible down and never pick it up again. The Bible should be studied TOPICALLY with a good study guide to get the best from it. I recommend this one, but there are others. Some will reject this stating it is a Jehovah’s Witness publication but almost every study guide is produced by one religious group or another. This can be obtained FREE of charge and downloaded at JW.ORG.  I also do NOT recommend the use of the King James Bible, the archaic language and sentence structure make it difficult to understand and get the correct meaning of many verses for the new student. I recommend the New American Standard Version, the New International Version, the International Standard Version or the New World Translation which can also be downloaded FREE of charge at the above website.

There are many ways on how to start reading the Bible. There are also many reading plans available, which are mostly free. Some tips to consider: Chronologically. Start with Genesis and Matthew. Then Exodus and Mark. From the Old Testament and the New Testament. This way you'll have an idea of the whole biblical picture.Start with the Gospel of John. This Gospel is considered the most loved and easy to understand Gospel. But supplement with the first five books of the Old Testament - Genesis to Deuteronomy, to grasp a better understanding.Don't just read from a single book everyday; it's like only eating rice with no viands and water. At least three books a day will do, to make it more balanced.Use a reading plan. There are 30-day reading plans and mostly there are one-year. Use the reading plan that will give you a reading from at least two-three books a day. That will be more healthy.Enjoy reading the Bible! Be challenged and changed!

Personally I would start with Luke. It give the account of the birth of the savior and also the genealogies. It is also the easiest to understand. It gives the life of Jesus in a chronological order. Acts is a great book but starts after the life of Christ. And we need to start at the beginning. John is also great a explaining many concepts that are not listed in other places. All books add something to the story but all books leave something out. The epistles of Paul were written to correct problems that were occurring in the church. The people were baptized but not fully converted and were bring some their other beliefs with them that were not Christian. Get a good bible. I recommend the King James Version. Some believe it to be the most accurate. Some include apocryphal writing.

Reading about the bible can be useful to help unpack the themes: RC Sproul’s Crucial Series[1] is great at helping to distil important doctrines - they’re pithy yet packed with wisdom. Better, they’re free.The Infographic Bible[2] is incredible, and well worth the money. It’s is chock-a-block with infographics on things I wouldn’t even have considered about in the bible, such as comparing where and how Jesus healed people (cross-referenced with how many at a time), or different poses in prayer and worship. It has a really fresh way of distilling the over-arching story of the Bible.The Spoken Gospel[3] project releases Spoken Word book introductions. It sounds cheesy. But David Bowden is a fine craftsman and has really helped me understand the main themes and crucially how they point to Jesus. So far they’ve done the Pentateuch and the Gospels.But as J.I Packer said in Knowing God. It is one thing to know about someone, but it is quite another to know them personally. Likewise the Bible. In order to get to know it, you need to read it for yourself. In doing so you get to rely on what it says for itself on its own terms. There are a great many tools and reading plans to help you get through it. But if you’re going for the over-arching message, one in which you read a book at a time is best. There is no harm in reading swathes at a time. 1 Corinthians is arguably pretty long, 16 chapters, but it is a letter that was intended to be read as a whole. You can go back and study questions later. Keep a record of your questions. I do so on a Trello Board. Often your questions are answered by other parts of the Bible itself. Other questions can be answered in many ways: Got Questions[4] is well known and loved - you can ask your own. A good study bible is helpful. On a practical note, I do it on YouVersion, which means I can do so on my phone, tablet, laptop, anywhere I am. My preference is for plans which take me through the Old Testament before reaching the New Testament - God arranged it in a way that His revelation is progressive. In other words, start with Revelation and you’ll miss a whole lot of information. Start with the Gospels, and you’ll not fully understand the prophesies. McCheyne’s plan, which ties Old and New Testaments together, is well loved by many but only good if you know what is happening in those passages to begin with. This year I’ve followed a chronological plan, which has the same events from different books together. That’s been useful to see how it ties together, but it got really choppy with some of the histories and the gospels. Next year I’m going to do a book at a time. Drilling down and discovering what each verse says is crucially important too - and that is a life-time’s work. It requires meditating on each verse bit by bit and asking questions of it. On this note I would absolutely recommend Dig Deeper by Nigel Benyen and Nigel Sachs.[5] It helps you know what kind of questions you should be asking! It is invaluable. Footnotes[1] Crucial Questions: 32 Free eBooks from R.C. Sproul[2] THE INFOGRAPHIC BIBLE[3] Book Introductions - YouTube[4] Bible Questions Answered[5] Dig Deeper - Nigel Beynon

When i started i started with interesting chapter Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher Then Gospel of Mark, Mathew , Luke and John. If you understand Gospel of John 14,15,16 and 17 chapters, then you understand what is what in this life that’s it Don’t think bible as a huge book of philosophy to break your head. Its a very simple plain book of truth burns every heart. All the best. Think about this after reading above in Gospel of John Then Pilate said to Jesus, 'So you are a king, are you?' Jesus answered, 'You say that I am a king. For this I was born, and for this I have come into the world, to bear witness to the truth. Everyone who is of the truth listens to my voice.' 38 Pilate said to him, 'What is truth?' Here Jesus didn’t answer this question but remains silent it means? Its my personal view : The true side of truth is peace

I agree with Noah - start with the Gospel of John. The four Gospels tell us about Jesus, his ministry, and his work from four distinct perspectives. Matthew is written to Jews and describes Jesus as the Christ (Messiah). Mark wrote about Jesus as the suffering servant who demonstrated the cost of obedience and discipleship, and his audience were gentiles living in Rome. Luke was written to the Greeks and showed the humanity of Jesus. John was written to show the divinity of Jesus Christ as Lord and God. If you are new to the faith, the best place to start is to understand that Jesus is God. Without that understanding then your faith will be in vain.

As many know, the Bible is not meant to be read cover to cover. The books of the Bible are organized according to the type of book. If you are new to reading the Bible and are just trying to learn the storyline of the Bible you could read Genesis, Exodus, Joshua, 1 Samuel, 2 Samuel, 1 Kings, 2 Kings, Ezra, Nehemiah, Habakkuk, Proverbs, Luke, Acts, Ephesians, Revelation These 15 books demonstrate the major themes and story of the Bible. Another way to read the Bible is to jump around the historical order of the books. John, Mark, Genesis, Exodus, Romans, Galatians, Matthew, Luke, Acts, Ephesians, Colossians Remember there is no correct way to read the Bible, I myself have never had a set way of reading the Bible. I have read the Bible a book at a time as I have grown closer to Jesus over the years. I hope that I have helped you, and may God bless you regardless of how you decide to read the Bible.

The Bible is a compilation of 66 books, so I think it is good to know where to start reading in the first place. I suggest starting with the teachings of Jesus in the 4 gospels (Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John). The reason why is because the whole Bible— both the Old and the New Testaments point to Jesus and his teachings, and also because Jesus’ teachings are the fulfillment of the rules in the Old Testament. If you are short on time, I suggest reading Jesus’ famous Sermon on the Mount in Matthew 5,6,and 7 because there are a lot of good teachings and wisdom there. As you read the teachings of Jesus, take Jesus literally and understand that what he said to his disciples was meant for all Christians. After all, disciples and Christians are the same thing (Acts 11:26). Try to apply his teachings to your life and literally do them. If you do, you’ll get so much more out of your reading than theologians and church pastors!

It depends on your goal. If you just want to read the Bible, so as to have that experience under your belt, you can start at Genesis and read through to Revelation. The order of the books was chosen with some care, after all, by people who took the Bible very seriously. A friend of mine once recommended starting with Ezra and Nehemiah, since they record the historical events that came just before the canon of the Bible started being collected. Then you could read the rest in order. If you are interested in a particular religious topic, you would want to choose other parts. Life of Christ? Read the Gospels in any order. Christian theology and moral teaching? The Epistles. The Problem of Evil? The book of Job. And so on.

Luke is a storyteller and detailed. He’s having a conversation with people that are unsure of who Christ is. Luke begins with the birth of Christ. It’s advisable to have a commentary and a side by side Bible (the free app Bible Hub has many Bible translations including side/by-side Greek (the language of the original Gospels). I go to a Bible Study that’s going through Luke slowly if you want to listen in on the podcasts. We take YEARS to get through a single Gospel! Previous Godpels (Matthew and Mark) are recorded by accessing our Parish media page. You can access the podcasts on : iTunes: Transforming our Lives in Christ (you can catch up because we’re only in chapter 2 of Luke) Fr Evan Armatas (Orthodox) Or: http://www.saintspyridon.church. Media, podcasts Or: Ancient Faith Radio Podcasts, Transforming our Lives in Christ (Fr. Evan Armatas)

It depends on how your planning to read it-If your looking from a theological viewpoint (analytical viewpoint) then you should read the gospels first and then go for Pauline Literature (Paul’s books) then go for the Old Testament. If your looking for a scholarly viewpoint (Study point) you should divide the Bible into different parts such as - Old Testament- Moses writings (Pentateuch or Torah) then go for the Prophet’s (Nevi’im) and at last go for Writings (Ketuvim). Remember that the Old Testament is very difficult to understand if you don’t apply your mind and connect especially when you read Nevi’im, I strongly suggest you should use several references and notes to understand several passages.New Testament- In terms of New Testaments the gospels are divided into 4 and then comes Pauline Literature. Start by reading the synoptic gospels ( Matthew,Mark,Luke) and then move to John and go for Paul, after Paul you may come up with other gospels such as James, Peter, Hebrews etc.In any way it depends on how you approach it, don’t rush and if you don’t understand a chapter then read it again until you get it.

Your question reminds me of Philip and the Ethiopian. And this is recorded in: Acts 8:26-35 Now an angel of the Lord said to Philip, “Go south to the road—the desert road—that goes down from Jerusalem to Gaza.” So he started out, and on his way he met an Ethiopian eunuch, an important official in charge of all the treasury of the Kandake (which means “queen of the Ethiopians”). This man had gone to Jerusalem to worship,and on his way home was sitting in his chariot reading the Book of Isaiah the prophet. The Spirit told Philip, “Go to that chariot and stay near it.” Then Philip ran up to the chariot and heard the man reading Isaiah the prophet. “Do you understand what you are reading?” Philip asked. “How can I,” he said, “unless someone explains it to me?” So he invited Philip to come up and sit with him.  This is the passage of Scripture the eunuch was reading: “He was led like a sheep to the slaughter, and as a lamb before its shearer is silent, so he did not open his mouth.In his humiliation he was deprived of justice. Who can speak of his descendants? For his life was taken from the earth.” The eunuch asked Philip, “Tell me, please, who is the prophet talking about, himself or someone else?” Then Philip began with that very passage of Scripture and told him the good news about Jesus.  Like the Ethiopian, it is difficult to understand the bible by yourself. What you need is to join a bible study, bring your bible, paper and pen - to explore its contents. There are bible studies conducted daily in the Church of Christ and I hope there is one near you. Normally these bible studies are conducted after 5 pm everyday.

Blessed is he who reads and those who hear the words of this prophecy ,and keep those things which are written in it. Rev.1.3. So reading is a blessing . First up all we must know that , inorder to reveal God to men God gave the Bible. Then how we start and from where you should start for reading. You can start reading from any portion of the Word of God. In the Bible history is there ,prophecy is there Gods law is there. If you are reading from any portion from the Bible and not understanding the full truth of the portion which youn read, you will be confused. Under standing and interpreting some portion of the word of God you should follow some rules.The first one I will tell for your information. “Contest theory”, while you are reading a portion from it you should know which contest it is written. A lot of people is misunderstood the word of God because of it. Now you are beginner I suggest , please read the gospel of the Bible , especially John gospel.it is written for telling Jesus is God .Read it very carefully, have a desire to know the truth of it .God looks the desire of the reader.Tell to the Holy spirit to make understand the particular portion.If you can't understand some part of it don't worry, mark it and later ask to somebody who is a truebeliver.Grdually the Spirit of God will help you .Please read this verse Luk 24.45. “And He opened their understanding ,that they might comprehend the scripture.”

The Gospel of John is a really good place to start as it's one of the easier gospels to read and the gospels are the main point of the Bible. After you're finished with John I'd recommend reading Genesis and Exodus and then, after those two, moving on to Acts and Romans. If you're a Christian and trying to study the Bible in order to learn more about your faith I'd suggest joining a local church and getting connected with people there who can help guide you. If you're reading the Bible for purely academic purposes I'd recommend reading the above and then starting back at Exodus 19 and reading straight through to Revelation.

Begin with the Gospel of John and then move forward to Acts and through the New Testament. (The four gospels more or less tell the same story.) When you start the Old Testament, you might decide which subject matter interests you most. For instance the books of the Old Testament are combined as follows: The first five books are the Law, from Genesis to Deuteronomy, and are also known as the Pentateuch. The History books are Joshua through Esther. The Poetic books are Job through the Song of Solomon. The Major Prophets are Isaiah through Daniel, and the Minor Prophets are Hosea through Malachi (minor means they are shorter, not less important).

The first three times I read through the entire Bible, I did it in this order. Mark, John, Matthew, Luke, Acts → Revelation, Genesis → Malachi. I chose Mark, John first for personal reasons. I would go New Testament reading Gospels of Matthew, Mark, John, and Luke in any order, the Acts→Revelation, then Genesis→Malachi. Then, do it again, Then, again. Then, keep on doing it, and never stop. But don’t put your own ideas and thoughts into it. Let God speak to you as you read. Just get to know him. You can do other specific studies where you think about things deeply and meditate more, but for just getting to know God, read it like a letter from him to you. Over and over until it become a part of you. Knowing God is the most important. Relying on your own understanding is a sin.

Genesis is a very good place to start in the Old Testament (OT), while also going through the Gospel of Matthew of the New Testament (NT). Work through the Torah (1st 5 Books OT) and the Gospels according to Mark, Luke, & John while keeping in mind the time in history of each reading and the fact that they transitioned into each other, the OT into the NT. After getting through the Torah and the Gospels start reading Joshuah, Judges, Ruth, 1 Samuel, 2 Samuel, 1 Kings, 2 Kings, NT readings Acts, James, 1 & 2 Peter, 1, 2, & 3 John, Jude, (aka Catholic or Jewish letters) after which read the Epistles of Paul (aka Pauline epistles). This was the actual ordering of the ancient Aramaic manuscripts, and the reason was that Paul’s letters teach concepts built on James, Peter, & John’s teachings. Reading the letters written by Paul first causes confusion as we see has happened in the Protestant movement, of whom many misunderstand and even dismiss all the New Testament for a few verses in Paul’s letters. Okay, get reading.

Sound out the big words and the foreign words. Use context clues. Summarize each chapter upon completion in your own words, in a way that a third grader could understand. ;) Or, actually, slightly more seriously, two options: (1) read it from beginning to end. This will take a LOT of discipline. But you will have an understanding few do, and be in a fairly small club, as vast majority of Christians have NOT done so. (2) Read it in three ways: (a) what does it say? What do the words mean? Who, What, Where, Why?; (b) read it metaphorically; (c) read it for the underlying deeper spiritual meaning. Remember that the Bible is a spiritual book. It is meant to help us understand life, how to live, God, nature, and help us become the best that we can. It is NOT a history book. It is NOT a science book.

Genesis,exodus, joshua, - old testament Gospel of john, gospel of Luke, the letterm to the Romans and then the letter to the hebrews. In the new testament. Then spread out from there. Ask God to help you understand even though much of it you may not. After multiple readings it becomes more clear. 66 books, 40 author's. Inspired by God. Written over a 3000 year period. It's a history and a message of love from our creator. Read it with an open mind. Jesus said we need to be like children . Trusting. Leave your preconceived notions at the door. Let the spirit teach you. God will teach you what you need to know now. God bless

First, get to know Jesus by reading the Gospel of John. Get to know the basic doctrines by reading Romans. Get familiar with missions and the work of the Spirit in Acts. Get devotional through the Psalms and become wise by reading Proverbs. Stress New Testament over Old until familiarized. Try not to concentrate on Revelation or reading out of curiosity! The epistles are all didactive or teaching, while the gospels and Acts are narrative or story-telling. You may want to begin with Genesis and Exodus, but don’t be discouraged if you get lost or bored after that! It’s all good but start with basics.

This is a broad question, and it depends where your interests lie. Genesis has perhaps the best story content, including a lot of subtleties that you will probably miss upon first reading. The Joseph narrative, which takes up about a fourth of the book, is unsurpassed in ancient literature. It stands on its own as a story without reference to any theological concerns. If you like sex and violence, you can’t beat the Book of Judges. If you are more interested in philosophy, Ecclesiastes would be my first choice. Job is a profound book but very hard to understand. For poetry, the Psalms are a good bet. Also “Song of Songs” (aka “Song of Solomon.”) I would recommend that you avoid the King James version, which is a marvelous example of Renaissance prose but often hard to understand. Newer translations, besides being easier to read, also have the advantage of scholarship that was not available hundreds of years ago. You may want to look into some commentaries also, or an annotated Bible. Many texts should not be taken at face value. Since I am Jewish, I am not familiar enough with the NT to make any recommendations about it. I will leave that to Christians who respond to this post.

There are “Reading plans” that people have created to help others read through the bible. Back to the Bible offers some different plans for different purposes and time lines. Personally, when I first became a believer, I just sort of let the spirit lead me if you will. And focused on the New Testament, finding the letters of Paul very useful to give me a good understanding of what the way was all about. If I knew your intent on reading the bible and your more about your faith, I could perhaps give you some better advice. I’d for sure pray for guidance and trust in the lord in guiding you. http://shorelinechurch.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/NewBelieverReadingPlan-Feb2014a-Final.pdf First Steps For New Believers: Day 1 http://www.firstbible.org/resources/helpfullinks/Bible%20Reading%20Chart-%20New%20Believer.pdf There are some other examples of reading plans. My best advice is to pray, let the spirit lead you, and keep an open heart and mind. And remember, the Bible is a collection of letters and histories written by men. Men of strong faith who were inspired by God. And that God preserved these writing for us, to help teach and guide us in our faith. But the real importance is our personal relationship with God. And sharing that relationship, that love, with others. God bless you my friend and feel free to contact me directly at trkenney35@gmail.com

Great question and very important that you ask it. The book of John is a good place to begin because John writes his purpose in this verse. John 20:30-31 30 And truly Jesus did many other signs in the presence of His disciples, which are not written in this book; 31 but these are written that you may believe that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of God, and that believing you may have life in His name. You will find faith strengthened by reading John. A second recommendation is to read one chapter in Proverbs each day. They will impart wisdom and you will find great insight into daily issues in proverbs. Be blessed in your reading.

awesome, i started with the book of matthew, i also remember reading Romans and then when i prayed, to learn how to pray, i learned from Luke 11, it was an immediate answer to prayer, :) learning to ask to pray by saying a prayer. i was prompted to turn on the tv even as i stood up and there on a christian network, a preacher/pastor was teaching Luke 11. later i also became very interested in the book of revelation and began reading the books where Elijah was prophet. However about 3 years after i became born again, where i had previously prayed to be baptized in the holy spirit, and saw the appearance of an angelic like being in my bedroom, i began praying to know which church to Join, because i believed there was only one true church. the spirit of revelation came upon me, and i was taught doctrines that only the Church of Jesus Christ of latter day saints teaches. the restoration of the Church is found in the LDS church, and a person should argue against its doctrines. i say it is the first step to get baptized into this church and learn the words of God in modern revelation given through JOseph Smith, the prophet of the restoration. Jesus said in the first vision to not join any of them… they are all “wrong”… thus saith the Lord.

You may start with the following summary of the Core teachings of Christianity: Jesus taught that when we obey God and do good works; we will pass the test of this world and will become qualified to receive God’s rewards in heaven In Matt 5:13-16, Jesus taught that the believers should act as the salt to protect against corruption and as a light to guide others to the truth The same is also written in mark 9:50 and Luke 14:34-35 In Matt 7:13-14, Jesus warned those who follow the majority “Enter through the narrow gate; for the gate is wide and the way is broad that leads to destruction, and there are many who enter through it. For the gate is small and the way is narrow that leads to life, and there are few who find it”. Most people ignore that teachings and say, ‘As long as I am with the majority, I should be fine’, but they are wrong according to the teachings of Jesus in Luke 13:24-27, Matthew 7:13-14 In Matt 7:15-20, Jesus warned from the false teachers who mislead people; he advised us to identify them from their bad deeds. In Matthew 7:21-23 Jesus warned of the false teachers who claim to perform miracles; he advised that only the believers who obey will enter the kingdom of heaven. The same is also written in Luke 13:25-27 In Matthew 22:35-40, Jesus confirmed the teachings of the Old Testimony like Deuteronomy 6:5 and Leviticus 18:4-5 Mark 12:33 teaches: And to love one’s neighbor as himself, is much more than all burnt offerings and sacrifices What Jesus taught here is not different from the wisdom taught by the old testimony Hosea 6:6 “For I desire mercy and not sacrifice, And the knowledge of God more than burnt offerings”. Luke 12:16-21 is a parable to warn most people who treasure for tomorrow while turning a blind eye to the hungry people we see everyday. John 12:25 warns those who like to "live it up" urging them to prepare for the eternal life. The same is also confirmed in Matthew 10:39 and Matthew 16:25 The same is also mentioned in Luke 9:23-25, Mark 8:34-35 Matthew 13:44 teaches us to give everything to obey so that we get God’s rewards for the righteous James 4:1-5 also warns those who compete to enjoy the pleasures of this life Luke 6:27-36 and Matthew 5:38-42 set the high standard for wise dealing with others; such teachings would replace hatred by compassion and would transform earth into a paradise. Matthew 7:12 reminds us of the “Golden Rule”, the common ground wisdom taught by all wise teachers and prophets. Matthew 6:24 urges us to shift from the material life into a spiritual life. Matthew 12:50 teaches that the real family of the prophet are the obedient believers. “For whoever does the will of my Father in heaven is my brother and sister and mother”. Luke 6:46-48 teaches that solid faith foundations are based on obedience to the teachings. The same is also taught in John 14:15 and John 14:21 “If you love me, you will keep my commandments”. John 14:21 “They who have my commandments and keep them are those who love me; and those who love me will be loved by my Father, and I will love them and reveal myself to them” In Matthew 25:31-45 Jesus described the final judgment as being based on good works; he clarified that those who obey the law will be saved. Salvation is not based solely on belief and nothing else; salvation is not granted to those who merely profess acceptance of Jesus without actually performing kind or compassionate deeds. Jesus did not teach that a man is justified by faith without the deeds of the law; In Matthew 16:27 and John 5:29, Jesus has confirmed that God will reward each person according to his deeds; those are the basic teachings of the old testimony like the verses taught in Psalm 62:12, Ecclesiastes 12:14, and many other old testimony verses. Matthew 25:41-46 teach that when we give the poor, we give to God . James 2:14 and 2:17 teach that faith without works is dead. Every one who has understood the bible will tell you that it was written precisely on how Jesus was manifested to the world; from the first sin and how God will make it right; Jesus (and His Kingdom) being the promise God made to Abraham. So, it will be way profitable for you if you start reading the bible from the first four books of the New Testament. It’s worth noting that what Jesus says in those books are what make/define a Christian, since Christians are disciples of Jesus. Once you understand and appreciate what Jesus taught in those books, practice them and then you should be in a better position to read and understand the whole bible. I hope this helps.

You are wise to think about reading the Bible. All scripture is good. If have not read the Bible before, I would start with the book of John. It tells who Christ is and how to be born again. "As newborn babes, desire the sincere milk of the word, that ye may grow thereby” 1 Peter 2:2 "And in His law he meditates day and night." Psalm 37:4 "All scripture is given by inspiration of God, and is profitable for doctrine, for reproof, for correction, for instruction in righteousness:" 2Ti 3:16 "The words of the LORD are pure words: as silver tried in a furnace of earth, purified seven times." Psalm 12:6

Page 1 is always a good place to start any book. But reader, beware! It is not always an easy read. Gen 10 -table of nations. Not quite as exiting for some as Gen 6 - the flood. So be prepared to struggle for some of the time. A good bible to get would be “The Chronological Bible.” A friend of mine published one, as an honor to his father, who had always dreamed os such a project. :Living in the days of computers, that became a lot easier! Narrated Bible in Chronological Order: New International Version (NIV) by F. Lagard Smith He will hasten to tell you that no, he is NOT the author…

Most modern readers are interested in story, rather than lists or translations of poetry. So I’d look for places in the Bible which tell stories. They are placed in matrices which set off the story. For example, once you have read Isaac’s story from the beginning — with the displacement of Ishmael and the near-sacrifice — you can understand the character of Isaac through the rest of his life. He doesn’t resist the native inhabitants of the land, but gives up his wells. He tries to avoid conflict. Thus when his younger son turns scoundrel, he doesn’t know how to handle it. He has to be told by his scheming wife that it would be wiser for Jacob to leave.

Question: I want to read the Bible. Where do I start? Start with Genesis ch. 1–11. That will give you the foundation of how everything got started, the flood, how languages came to be, etc. Then move on to the book of John and the rest of the New Testament. Keep in mind that John chapter three is the central theme of the whole Bible. It is a good idea to read one chapter of Proverbs a day, that will make you wise if you do what it says. Come back around and read Matthew, Mark, and Luke as well, realizing that some of the stories are repeated in the gospels. Then if you like you can explore more of the O.T. It is filled with interesting stories, keep in mind that all those sacrifices were temporary until Jesus came to be the perfect sacrifice for sin. And it is very messy in there as well, with people doing a lot of killing for whatever reasons. How God dealt with Israel is a large topic there.

Of course, you can start at the beginning. However, some first-time readers find it easier to start with the Gospels​—Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John—​the accounts of Jesus’ life and ministry. Then some proceed to the beautifully written and wisdom-packed poetic books​—Psalms, Proverbs, and Ecclesiastes. After that, your appetite may be whetted for other parts of the Bible. And do not adopt the false notion that you only need to read what is commonly called the New Testament. Remember, “all Scripture is inspired of God and beneficial.”​—2 Timothy 3:16.

I would Read Genesis the first book first in order to give backstory to the new testament and to establish the setting of the world. Than you could go to either Matthew,Mark, luke or John to learn about Christ and his story for the world. Know that Matthew was addressed to the Jewish populace. Luke and Mark for the Gentile and John is a gospel heavily focused on Gods character and make up. Although any of these should be adequate in retaining the gospel Mark or Luke may be more simple to retain at first. After all that you could go on to Acts-Revelations to learn instruction If you are Christian or just curious. Also if the Jewish peoples history interests you Exodus on to through Job would be nice. Hope you find This useful but don’t trust me. Trust the Bible.

Depends on who you are, what you are expecting to achieve and what info you want to find by reading it. If you never read it, and you want to read main parts of Bible, that are building blocks of christian religion, you could maybe start with Matthew, Mark, Lucas and John, and proceed then to Genesis and Exodus. But to answer this question properly I would need more info about your reasons why you want to read Bible :)

I commend the other answerers for useful and insightful advice. I hope that this is also useful. First, prepare yourself to read the Bible. Be openBe honestBe inquisitiveSecond, suspend judgment about what you read. Make notes of questions that you have, and also observations and insights. Ask God to make you aware when what you now read answers a question from an earlier reading.Finally, recognize that the Bible was written from another dimension - outside of time. It is holographic in nature, with unique textual attributes and mathematical properties contained in no other literature ever written. A great guide to approaching the Bible is Chuck Missler’s “Learn the Bible in 24 Hours” (www.KHouse.org).

I will refer to the old testament (or Tanach) only since I'm much more familiar with it. If you really want to understand it properly, you should study the following languages before : Biblical Hebrew (and grammar)Aramic. (Especially for the book of Daniel)Your next stage will be studying the Bible in its original language with basic Jewish commentators like Rashi - Wikipedia. Which will help you understand the simple meaning of the verses, though a bit Jewish inclined interpretation which you may ignore if you find it too inclined. You must learn the followings too: The historical background of the books you are reading.The geography and borders of the territories which were occupied by ancient nations in Israel and in its vicinity. And finally, you have to read the Bible several times in order to do cross correlation between different texts. Good luck!

In my opinion, the best book to start reading is the gospel of John. You could also follow a daily devotional like ‘Our daily bread’. Or you could purchase a Bible with commentary to understand the scripture better. Studying the Bible together with a friend or a church Bible study group is very beneficial too. Either way, we need strength and guidance from the scripture each and every day of our lives. More than reading, it is important to meditate and apply God’s truth in our lives. I have found the SOAK method very useful for my Bible study. S stands for important scripture verses or verses that stand out, O stands for the objective of the scripture passage you read, A stands for the application (how one can apply the scripture in his/her life), K stands for Kneeling in prayer (Say or write a prayer requesting God to use the passage of scripture to change and make you more like Him). I hope this helps, my friend!

Pray and Read a chapter of John a day - this is all about Jesus and the Gospel. It’s wonderful when paired with a couple of Psalms a day, which are heartfelt expressions of praise, anguish, prayer, and thanksgiving. Ask for Jesus to open your eyes to the word and to change you and watch over you all the day long. God bless you, dear one, may you find Jesus new each and every day both reading and in experiencing Christ’s love fresh throughout the day.

Read the first sentence of the Bible. When one truly understands what it says, read the rest of the chapter. Just to be clear, I was in my mid-20’s, when I first understood what the first sentence means. I had to chew on it for another 45 years before I really understood it. Then, I knew the difference between the narrow and the wide gates. Lacking this understanding, most people find in the Bible only the broad road.

A brand new life of faith begins when we place our trust in Jesus Christ. Start is the perfect Bible for new believers or believers who want to learn more about their faith. Ideal for introducing new believers to the Bible, Start focuses on basic discipleship with articles and devotions on subjects including prayer, Bible study, church involvement, sharing your faith, and discovering God's will. Core biblical themes are introduced at basic levels of theological sophistication and presented in very simple language. Start! The Bible for New Believers: New King James Version, Red, Study

The first three chapters of Genesis are the key to seeing the meaning in the rest. What makes life, life? Then there’s Eden and the Tree of Knowledge. Eden is paradise, of sorts. If we stayed in Eden, we would be rather dull Beings. Knowledge is where the unknown is found. The unknown is also where the trouble is. After that, The Bible is basically about humanity navigating the path between order and chaos (Moses, Noah, Job, Daniel etc), and the notion that Beings can always come back to what is Godly. I think Judeo-Christians do a great disservice to themselves when they dehumanize The Bible.

Probably the worst way is to start with Gen 1:1 and just keep going straight forwards. But without knowing more about what you are trying to do, it is hard to advise you where to start. I can tell you that one famous Bible reader started with the Gospel of Mark mainly because it was the shortest of the Gospels. But it changed his life, he became a monk and then a bishop.

Start with the stories of Genesis, then read through the rest of the Hebrew Bible with Israel as the center, then read the Gospels, seeing them as a Jewish group who believe they have seen the Jewish Messiah, then read the Epistles as letters to specific groups teaching them how to apply the news of the Gospels to their otherwise Jewish religious practice as commanded by the Messiah in Matthew 28:18-20.

You can also request a free booklet called “How to Study the Bible and Have it Make Sense” from our friends at Christian Resources, simply by clicking here.. FREE Booklet - How to Study the Bible

Well…since I disagree with your only answer received I’ll throw in my 2 cents. If you are a new Christian start with the book of John (unless you are Jewish..start with Mathew). The Gospel of John was written for the Gentile (anyone that isn’t Jewish) to understand the plan and love of God for humanity.

I would highly recommend you start with the Gospels - the book of John first preferably. Then go to the rest of the New Testament. After that, go to the Old Testament - the Pentateuch first, then the rest of the Old Testament. This recommendation is based on relevancy if you want to know more about Jesus Christ and Christianity.

Academic course, so you learn what the bible says and what has been removed and what is of dubious origin and so on. I’m not a Bible scholar and I’m not looking for a debate, but in my opinion I think “Matthew” is a good starting point. I also think the first part of “Genesis” is a good place for a beginner to start reading. I think that’s how I started some 35 years ago and I’m still reading the Bible today. God bless.

The Gospel of Mark is a good place to start. John is pretty good too. From my perspective, the Bible is a spiritual book, so I would suggest reading it with spirit. Dr. Ruth says the entire Bible is a sex manual. I don’t have expertise in that area, so in that respect, I would suggest Dr. Ruth.

Start on page one, that is the Book of Genesis. The beginning. The Old Testament is the old biblical tales, such as Noah’s Ark, Moses, Sodom and Gomorrah and the ancient tales of man and God. The New testament is the testimony of the life of Jesus from the disciples. I suggest reading it chronologically, so you know where it started and what the modern doctrines are. It is an interesting read. You can stop and start.

I would suggest finding a good church with a very good pastor who had the heart of a teacher and was diligent in his calling, and start attending. Go to Bible study on Wednesday night in between Sunday services and learn how to read, study, and understand the Bible with the guidance of some experienced followers and devout Christians.

I suggest the Gospel of John (or John for short) it's the most popular of the four gospels. I also highly recommend reading the New Testament first, because when I started reading the Bible cover to cover I became very bigoted because I didn't know about the New Covenant yet, and I tried to follow the law of Moses for that reason. Good luck on your journey, and always seek the truth. ✌🏻

Start at Psalm 137:9. Then read the whole psalm for clarity. If you still feel like reading after that, start from the book of Genesis. Oh, in case you’re too lazy to look up the verse, here it is (King James Version):“Happy shall he be, that taketh and dasheth thy little ones against the stones.”

To learn from the Bible. There is only one way. Read the Bible over and over again. Don't try to compare things that was written in the Bible to your present day situations. Compare the Bible with only the Bible. And then after learning from the Bible alone, compare other writings and history according to what you learned from the Bible.

I don’t understand what reading the Bible has to do with learning. A lot of people start learning without ever having read the Bible. By the same token, a lot of people who have read the Bible start learning, as well. It doesn’t seem to have any effect on whether you can learn or not.

The Bible has many different genres: poetry, historical narrative, apocalyptic, etc. If a person wants to know who we are, why we are here, and why the world is in such a mess, then Genesis is a great place to start. It is easy to read because it is written in the form of a historical narrative. However, if a person wants to know about Jesus and how he is the answer to and the redeemer of those questions, then the book of John in the New Testament is the place to start. Like Genesis, John is also written in the form of a historical narrative.

Take you bible. Open it exactly to the center. See the 6 page chapter named Ecclesiastes? Start there. It’s the most honest and moral and wonderful book in the Bible. It will make you happy to be alive. Start there. PS: You will find no god talk. Just honesty and high morals. Things lacking in nearly every other book of the Bible.

I was bored by the Bible until I took a class called “The Bible as History,” where I learned that these were people like us, with crises and disappointments and joys. Kings had King problems, mothers had mother problems. I’ve also enjoyed listening to the preaching of the Rev. William Barber, who brings the Bible stories into modern life with verve and relevance.

Before any biblical reading program, focus on programming your heart and spiritual eyes to God’s Word. Anyone can glance through the 700,000+ words of Scripture and yet miss the heart of God. Ask the Lord’s Holy Spirit to be your guide in teaching what He feels is pertinent for your life and circumstance. And then, begin reading …. and enjoy.

I would read Mark and John. Then read Genesis and then read John again. After that, I would set about reading the Bible all the way through. If you are brave, read and reread a book several times through. I did this with Genesis. It completely changed my understanding of Genesis and the Bible as well.

the best starting point is to read the Bible from the very beginning Genesis to the end Book of Revelation. It’s important to see the very foundation of man and God at the beginning and how man fell from Gods grace. It is equality important to read the prophecy of our Savior; His birth, Journey, life, death and resurrection

Read John. Make sure you ask God to teach you to understand what you are reading. I’d go to Matthew or Luke after that. Luke was written in chronological order. Matthew, Mark and Johnare written to emphasize the character traits the writers focused on.

I would recommend the Book of John. Then read the other three of the four books of the gospel. JOHN 1 KJV Then begin at Genesis and read through Exodus. It would also help to join a local bible study group, and speak to a saved Christian pastor. Jesus saves.

Start from Genesis and make your way through the whole Bible. I guess the wording is from Version to Version differently. I, for example, have the Protestant Bible. It would take an effort to go through the whole thing but i guess it is worth it. Everyone has to decide for themselves. Good Luck

Start with the Old Testament and read as much of it as you can stand. Ideally, read it all to discover how many crazy, unscientific, cruel things are in it. Do Not just read the parts your Pastor tells you about. It is to his advantage that you don’t read all of it because that’s how some of us have become atheists.

It’s best you not even open that book. Many deluded souls claim it is history, when in fact it’s pages are filled with stories so far-fetched and out of touch with reality that it’s hard to believe anybody woukd take it as fact. Unless you believe that men return from the dead, others live for days inside the belly of a big fish, or that virgins give birth, you can look upon it as mythology.

The first time I felt like I finally had a decent understanding of the Bible was when I read the entire thing a few times, cover to cover. Each read through shouldn’t take too long—a couple months at the most if you spend just a few minutes on it a day. After a few full readings of the Bible, one begins to see why generations of theologians and philosophers of religion have yet to agree on a unified interpretation of the Bible’s many genres and worldviews.

There are a few interesting concepts in the Old Testament. I skipped a lot of it. The concept of God evolving, perfecting in Exodus 3:14: “I will become what I become”. Skip Saint Paul too. Jesus in John 1:1 is the Logos or Logic, that which is not logical is not of God. Paul is trite and illogical, he’s the problem with Christianity. My favorite Old Testament book is the story of Jonah, who was told to prophesy against Nineveh. I found that inspiring. Jesus was radical, revolutionary, he told the truth about the religious hypocrites of his day and was crucified for it. He said, “you cannot serve God and money… but the Pharisees who loved money heard all this and scoffed”.

Hi start with the New Testament, from the beginning with love, ask God to help U to know what he wants U to know, and see how much God loves all of us, I read from AKJV 1611 Holy Bible, much love many blessings Gbu L Peter keep a note book and write things down which bits that U feel touched U or sort of stands out to U, and references to look it up again
Don’t start with the bible. Start with the introduction, preface, foreward. These will give you a clue in understanding the bible and in understanding the translators’ intent.

Read Gospel of John , Matthew ,Mark and Luke First. Secondly - Read Book of Acts till Revelation. But Don't read Revelation. Thirdly- Read Genesis to Malachi . Old Testament full. This is the perfect way of Reading the Bible. May the Lord speak to you and bless you abundantly Sham Kumar

Start right at the very beginning and read thoroughly right to the end. Make sure to keep an exercise book beside you and several pens to write down all of the inconsistencies and all of the contradictions. Dont forget to keep a tally of the innocent people/races/cities that god destroys or commands to be destroyed or gives away.

In my personal opinion I would say that in order for someone to learn about the bible they should reread the chapters they don't understand. I would say that notes help as well. Meditating on the bible and putting what the bible says, in practice, will help us have knowledge of the bible as well.

Ummm, I hate to be obtuse, but . . . at the beginning! Genesis 1.1 . . . then slowly, and meditatively, read and study each verse. If you have a study Bible, that is with other verses referenced, read the reference verses, too. It will take you a while, but the whole Bible fits together like peas in a pod, or meshing gears. You will see that if you . . . begin at the beginning. God bless you- is my prayer for you.

Begin at the beginning. When you can’t take it any more, the small mindedness, the stupidity, the sexism, the prejudice, the random violence, and the total lack of sanity, just stop. And don’t start ever again. Once should be enough.

Numbers 31; 17—18.Numbers 33; 50—56.Then read the entire book of numbers and then go back to start reading the entire bible from page one.DO NOT read the new testament until AFTER you’ve read Numbers and paid attention to what you read therefrom.

Start with John's Gospel. It reads like a Greek play with intrigue and irony. Watch for symbols along the way, especially darkness and light have meanings. Welcome to the Bible. It is a most interesting discovery.
Start with reading New Testament. The Good News for you is in the New Testament. The Old Testament is the background only. Read New Testament and follow the teachings of Jesus.

I always recommend to start with Mark’s Gospel. It is easy to read and quite short and all the other gospels are based on it (yes, even John). Surely the gospels are a good place to start! Be warned, it may change your life.

Please listen to “The Hidden Gospel- 1&2” messages, on this website: www.jesuslovesme.org. It tells you of the Grace of God in Jesus Christ. I’d suggest reading “The God Delusion” first. I assume you mean the Christian Bible and it’s a work of fiction with some good and bad ideas in it but start from a logical foundation before being bombarded by superstitious nonsense.

There are may ways to do it. But i started at Genesis and on to Revelation. Next time i used a Bible Commentary . I would suggest one to help you. Will keep reading it over and over. I find out more or understand more each time. You will find your own way too.

This is a great question. I suggest beginning at the the Gospel of John because it gives a wonderful introduction to Jesus Christ, his character, his teaching, his purpose and what he desires for all mankind.

Start with the New Testament first, then after completion, the Old Testament. Never let anyone tell you that the Old Testament is irreverent, for every scripture quoted in the New Testament comes from the Old Testament. May the Lord bless you on this journey and enable you to complete it. May he also give you revelations that you otherwise would not have known in Jesus’ name we pray, Amen!

Pray; believing that the Holy Spirit would reveal His purposes in preserving this set of texts; that He would reveal the Saviour of mankind, our wonderful Lord Jesus, to you through your reading. Start at the beginning and read through to the end.

I would start with the book of romans; but I would also look at the Bible project as well which is non-profit and breaks down each book and certain words in scripture pretty well; here’s one of my favorite
I think it is good to start with gospels. For the jews St mathews gospel is good to start. If you are philosophically sound Johns gospel is suggested. Otherwise Lukes gospel is the best to start.

Start at the New Testament. Read that a few times then work on the Old Testament. Go buy some Christian books for study. Attend bible study classes. Ask a church mate a whole lotta questions and listen to what they say.
Purchase a Holy Bible, KJVRead from Genesis to RevelationRepeat step 2The books of the Bible are in the order that they are in for a reason, and that order is correct.

Alone with no interruption, one book at a time they are all short. Absolutely no classes. Every religion has a different explanation of what they want it to mean. You can understand they meaning by yourself. Do not read The Song of Solomon if you are under 18.

John or Mathew. I’m on 10th time through the Bible and I’ll read a New Testament then old and just go back and forth. The stories in Genesis, particularly about Joseph are fantastic. Of course the easy books are Psalms and Proverbs.
If you have never read the bible that is a good start in itself.
From the beginning - Genesis , the earlier books are in more of a story book format so it’ll be interesting and help you get into the flow of reading it :)

Start with Luke and John, then read the rest of the New Testament , praying for understanding and asking shod your help you to apply it. Also go to a church where the gospel is preached in the power of the Holy Spirit.

Start with John. That will give u the badic info on who and what God is. Next go to Genesis. The first 5 books are reallya good understanding. Then i suggest the New Testament.
